isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics Model Years 1999-2000 - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - DIAGNOSTIC PROCEDURES FOR THE ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM - Connector Voltage Checks

svcproc.title: Connector Voltage Checks

step1.para: Plug breakout tee into the harness connector.
Measure voltage at each pin with a digital volt ohmmeter (DMM).
Compare sensor or actuator voltage readings with the expected voltages listed in the diagnostic section.

svcproc.para: If a breakout tee is not available, use the correct tool from terminal test adapter kit ZTSE 4435. Do not directly probe the connector terminals with the DMM leads. For a circuit with an expected voltage, this test will verify circuit integrity.
For circuits without an expected voltage, this test will determine if that circuit is shorted or miswired to Vref, B+ or other voltage sources.
V REF D: EOP, MAP, CMP, ICP

item.para: Signal return circuits measure 0 - 0.25v for a pull down circuit or close to 5v or 12v for a pull up circuit.

Actuator circuits are ON/OFF or Pulse Width Modulated (PWM). If the actuator has an ON/OFF circuit, the ECM controls the voltage or ground. If the actuator has a PWM circuit, the ECM controls the duty cycle or on time for power or ground.

V REF should measure 5 ± 0.5 volts (4.5 - 5.5V) with the sensor disconnected. If the voltage reading is lower than expected, disconnect sensors in the same V REF circuit (one at a time), and check V REF voltage.
If V REF voltage returns after disconnecting a sensor, that sensor is shorting V REF to ground.
